rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c00a57a5.1503">   <title>Re: Normalization error in 2D classification after rescaling particles </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c00a57a5.1503</link>   <description> It is a problem that we always encounter. For some reason, every time we downscale and normalize at the same time our particles in relion_preprocess, we get this error message.<br>I usually fix this issue by re-normalizing the already decimated stacks, and then it works.<br>It’s as if relion was normalizing the images before downsizing instead of the opposite. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T18:02:44-04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Amedee des Georges</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c00a57a5.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;a84576d0.1503">   <title>Re: Unregularized reconstruction from classification </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;a84576d0.1503</link>   <description> Hi Amedee,<br>Regularization is an intrinsic part of the reconstruction algorithm within<br>the classification procedure, so the answer to your question is no. You<br>could however use relion_reconstruct of the particles in their optimal<br>orientations. Alternatively, run auto-refine on each class.<br>HTH,<br>S<br><br>&gt; Hello Everyone,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Is there a way to get unregularized (unfiltered) reconstructions at the<br>&gt; end of a classification iteration? I don\ufffd\ufffdt see an option for it, even<br>&gt; though we can get regularized half-set maps.<br>&gt;<br>&gt; By advance, many thanks,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Amedee<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt; --<br>&gt; --<br>> Amedee des [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T16:50:11-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;a84576d0.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;850f035e.1503">   <title>Unregularized reconstruction from classification </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;850f035e.1503</link>   <description> Hello Everyone,<br><br>Is there a way to get unregularized (unfiltered) reconstructions at the end of a classification iteration? I don’t see an option for it, even though we can get regularized half-set maps.<br><br>By advance, many thanks,<br><br>Amedee<br><br>--<br>--<br>Amedee des Georges<br>Frank lab<br>Howard Hughes Medical Institute<br>Dept. of Biochemistry and Molecular Biophysics<br>650 W 168th St, P&amp;S Black Building room 221<br>New York, NY 10032<br>(T) 212 305-9527<br>(F) 212 305-9500<br>(E) ad2720@columbia.edu<br>http://franklab.cpmc.columbia.edu<br>Google Scholar Profile    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T11:34:17-04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Amedee des Georges</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;850f035e.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6d6d3c10.1503">   <title>Re: Normalization error in 2D classification after rescaling particles </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6d6d3c10.1503</link>   <description> Hi Ali,<br>If you've checked there are no all-black particles or the like, I guess<br>this is OK. Just to be sure: you are scaling down (by a factor 1/2),<br>right? Scaling up would not make sense and should be avoided.<br>HTH,<br>S<br><br>&gt; Hey Everyone,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I re-scale my auto-picked particles by a factor of 2 using the rescale<br>&gt; option in particle extraction and normalize them by indicating 'yes' in<br>&gt; the Normalize particles option. When I run 2D classification with these<br>&gt; particles, I get an error message stating that the particles have not been<br>> [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T08:34:55-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6d6d3c10.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;88abfd63.1503">   <title>Re: relion: write out star file containing CTF parameters referring to an mrcs stack </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;88abfd63.1503</link>   <description> Hi Dieter,<br><br>what is the input do you have here? A set of particles in separated stacks<br>and the CTF parameters in other files? In that case how is the<br>correspondence?<br>Or do you have another Relion star file and you want to merge all particles<br>in a single mrcs file? If you provide more details maybe I can help you<br>with a simple<br>script to do the task. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-12T07:50:12+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Jose Miguel de la Rosa Trevin</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;88abfd63.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e3133b4.1503">   <title>Normalization error in 2D classification after rescaling particles </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e3133b4.1503</link>   <description> Hey Everyone,<br><br>I re-scale my auto-picked particles by a factor of 2 using the rescale option in particle extraction and normalize them by indicating 'yes' in the Normalize particles option. When I run 2D classification with these particles, I get an error message stating that the particles have not been normalized. Since I know I normalized my particles in the particle extraction step, is it ok to go on with 2d classification using the --dont_check_norm option? [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T16:51:08+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ali Khan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e3133b4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f021e974.1503">   <title>relion: write out star file containing CTF parameters referring to an mrcs stack </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f021e974.1503</link>   <description> Hi Sjors and all,<br>how do I make an mrcs stack (containing all images) and a<br>corresponding star file (containing the ctf parameters)? When using<br>'relion_preprocess --operate_on' the resulting star file does not<br>contain the ctf parameters that were present in the original star file.<br>Thanks, Dieter   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-11T05:38:12+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dieter Blaas</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f021e974.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e34adf3.1503">   <title>Re: Question on Relion Tutorial Data </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e34adf3.1503</link>   <description> Hi Ali,<br>There are many other factors in collecting data apart from how many movie<br>frames you record, so I'm not sure how relevant this is. But Richard<br>Henderson and Shaoxia Chen collected the original (non-downsampled)<br>betagal data using 16 frames/second on our Falcon-II camera (that was<br>hacked by Greg McMullan to allow access to all frames), at a dose rate of<br>~1 e/A^2/frame. The relevant references are in the tutorial (refs. 9, 2 &amp;<br>13).<br>HTH,<br>S [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T21:08:54-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;8e34adf3.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;189f4221.1503">   <title>Re: Temp files for all probability-weighted sums of the model </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;189f4221.1503</link>   <description> Hi Chris,<br><br>I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm not sure about writing files to scratch space, but I do know that if you specify the option --dont_combine_weights_via_disc Relion will calculate the weights over the network instead of through the disc, which will solve the problem of writing out temporary files.<br><br>Here are two email exchanges where this problem was discussed:<br>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;41f787d1.1501<br>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;3ef1c723.1412 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T15:14:04+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Cianfrocco, Michael</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;189f4221.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;726bef3b.1503">   <title>Question on Relion Tutorial Data </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;726bef3b.1503</link>   <description> Hi,<br><br>We're trying to reproduce the beta-galactosidase reconstruction with data from our microscope and detector, and we are curious about your imaging conditions. For the images in the relion tutorial, how many chunks or frames did you collect on your falcon for each image? We collected seven chunks with two second total exposure time in movie mode and aligned them, but our aligned micrographs do not look as good as the ones in the tutorial. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T14:57:21+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ali Khan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;726bef3b.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b001127f.1503">   <title>Temp files for all probability-weighted sums of the model </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b001127f.1503</link>   <description> Hello,<br><br>While running RELION I understand it writes out temporary files to distribute all probability-weighted sums of the model (Copy pasted from the FAQ). My question is whether there is a way to tell RELION to write it out to each nodes scratch space? Does each process need access to all the temp files written out while running? [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T14:35:34+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Christopher Lilienthal</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b001127f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;4ff4613c.1503">   <title>Re: modelling tools </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;4ff4613c.1503</link>   <description> Hi TC,<br><br>I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdm currently trying to best fit a model to an EM map and have been using<br>phenix. I\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdve had some help from Pavel and running something along the lines<br>of this keeps my Ramachandran looking pretty good (use latest nightly<br>build):<br><br>phenix.real_space_refine *.pdb *.mtz ncs.eff rama_potential=oldfield<br><br>Also, if you have high resolution structures that are part of your starting<br>model \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd you can define the secondary structure and phenix will read these<br>from the header. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T10:47:35+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Valerie Pye</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;4ff4613c.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e2f568e8.1503">   <title>Re: modelling tools </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e2f568e8.1503</link>   <description> Hi Tc,<br><br>Just a general observation to stir up the discussion, as I'm eager to hear<br>the opinion of others on this important topic.<br><br>I think a 4.4A map is still rather low resolution to allow for a<br>well-defined refinement of the atomic model (e.g. where angles remain in<br>the allowed regions of the Ramachandran plot without proactively forcing<br>them in there), and this likely holds for most refinement programs out<br>there. The 3.5A in the best region of your map may be good enough, but at<br>resolutions lower than 3.8-4A things start becoming much more difficult as<br>side chain [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T08:28:08-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e2f568e8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;372cb95f.1503">   <title>Re: C3 tetrameric symmetry </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;372cb95f.1503</link>   <description> Hi Sjors and Marin<br><br>Thanks for your symmetry tutoring, which helped a lot.<br>The fact that \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdT&quot; already contains 12 asymmetric units explains the nice map I got from a fairly small number of particles ;)<br><br>Thanks and best,<br>Sebastian<br><br>&gt; On Mar 9, 2015, at 11:01 PM, Sjors Scheres &lt;scheres@mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk&gt; wrote:<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Thanks Marin! I mis-read Sebastian's message. So, Sebastian, in that case<br>&gt; you've already done what you should do. :-)<br>&gt; In general, when in doubt about symmetry operators, one could use:<br>&gt; &quot;relion_refine --sym T --print_symmetry_ops&quot; to get a list of all of them.<br>> [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T08:44:24+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Scherer Sebastian</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;372cb95f.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;7ce75e19.1503">   <title>Re: modelling tools </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;7ce75e19.1503</link>   <description> Dear Tc,<br><br>For Refmac there is no need to convert the mrc file prior to refinement. Using the script available from Garib's website (http://www2.mrc-lmb.cam.ac.uk/groups/murshudov/) simply specify the map in its original format:<br><br>./refine.csh -m map.mrc -i model.pdb -o output_folder -r restraints_folder -s refine.settings<br><br>If your structure has homologs solved at higher resolution, you can use distance information from these in the form of external restraints, which may help to stabilise your Ramachandran plot. Altering the weight of these external restraints on the basis of the local resolution should help in cases like yours where there is heterogeneity. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T07:10:17+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alan Brown</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;7ce75e19.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;884dcb99.1503">   <title>modelling tools </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;884dcb99.1503</link>   <description> Hi all,<br><br>I am building / refining a model on a ~4.4A map using coot, and then use phenix.real_space_refine for refinement, which cleans up the clashes, and bond length/ angles nicely, but somehow screws up the Ramachandran plot. I guess part of the reason could be that the resolution isn't uniform across the whole EM map, (3.5 to 5A in my case), so that may confuse the program about the b-factor distribution in the map.<br>I guess Refmac is the refinement program that many people here are using, but I am curious on what other refinement program is popular, and [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-10T00:28:44+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Tc</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;884dcb99.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb1b1cb8.1503">   <title>Re: C3 tetrameric symmetry </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb1b1cb8.1503</link>   <description> Thanks Marin! I mis-read Sebastian's message. So, Sebastian, in that case<br>you've already done what you should do. :-)<br>In general, when in doubt about symmetry operators, one could use:<br>&quot;relion_refine --sym T --print_symmetry_ops&quot; to get a list of all of them.<br>For T it gives 12 operators, for the 12 &quot;monomers&quot;.<br>HTH, S<br><br>&gt; Hi Sebastian,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; I think there is some misunderstanding here. The 'T' point-group<br>&gt; symmetry has a minimum of 12 asymmetric units; it has four 3-fold axes,<br>&gt; and six 2-fold axes. The orientation of the T point-group symmetry<br>> within a Cartesian X-Y-Z [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T22:01:40-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb1b1cb8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6b8458b8.1503">   <title>Open Position for Young Group Leader in (amongst others) Computational Biophysics and Structural Biology </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6b8458b8.1503</link>   <description> Dear colleagues,<br>There is a job opening for young investigators in the field of<br>/*Computational Biophysics and Structural Biology*/ (attached). For our<br>current microscopy equipment please see:<br>http://www.csf.ac.at/facilities/electron-microscopy/. We shall have a<br>Gatan K2 in April. I would be very happy to see the establishment of a<br>cryo-EM single particle group here in Vienna! Please spread the word!<br>Best, Dieter   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-09T15:20:15+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Dieter Blaas</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6b8458b8.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;d9c5b6fb.1503">   <title>Re: CTF star file </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;d9c5b6fb.1503</link>   <description> Dear Qiu-Xing,<br><br>Ctffind4 implements heuristics to try to &quot;boost&quot; high-frequency rings so<br>that they may be seen more easily in the diagnostic image and in the 1D<br>plots. The problem with those heuristics is that they create<br>artefactural features when the fitted CTF and the experimental<br>amplitudes do not agree anymore (i.e. at high frequencies). You are<br>pointing out such artefacts in your attachment. Be assured though that<br>these weird features are only occuring in the diagnostic image and there<br>is no such heuristic being used when doing the actual fitting. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-08T19:32:05-04:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Alexis Rohou</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;d9c5b6fb.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f9abbe11.1503">   <title>Re: CTF star file </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f9abbe11.1503</link>   <description> Dear all,<br>We switched to CTFfind4 recently. It worked well. Meanwhile, as showed in<br>the enclosed png file (pixel 1.05 A), we noticed that there is a circular<br>mask to ~2.92 angstrom, and beyond that resolution, there were evenly<br>spaced rings in the background. It does not affect the accuracy of the<br>fitting. I am curious to know whether anyone in this group noticed the<br>same and/or tried to get rid of the background. Thanks. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-08T22:59:18+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Qiu-Xing Jiang</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f9abbe11.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b8ecd760.1503">   <title>Re: C3 tetrameric symmetry </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b8ecd760.1503</link>   <description> Hi Sebastian,<br><br>I think there is some misunderstanding here. The 'T' point-group<br>symmetry has a minimum of 12 asymmetric units; it has four 3-fold axes,<br>and six 2-fold axes. The orientation of the T point-group symmetry<br>within a Cartesian X-Y-Z co-ordinate system is normally along a set of<br>orthogonal 2-fold axes. The 222 (=D2) pointgroup symmetry is a subset of<br>the T (=23) pointgroup symmetry, the way the 222 pointgroup symmetry is<br>a subset of the the Icosahedral (=532) pointgroup symmetry. (See:<br>http://www.singleparticles.org/methodology/MvH_Pointgroup_Symmetry.pdf).<br>There thus always are 3 asymmetric units ('monomers') around each 3-fold<br>axis of the 'T' pointgroup symmetry [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-08T12:05:45+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Marin van Heel</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;b8ecd760.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c387ab3e.1503">   <title>Re: C3 tetrameric symmetry </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c387ab3e.1503</link>   <description> Hi Sebastian,<br>I guess that what you are describing is a case of &quot;local&quot; symmetry, i.e.<br>it is not true symmetry in that it does not hold for the entire particle.<br>If this is the case, then you should run a refinement in tetrameric<br>symmetry (like you did), then cut out the 3 pseudo-symmetrical subunits<br>from the unfil.mrc maps, and then use some 3D program to align and average<br>over these 3 subunits. This will give you a further improvement in<br>resolution for your subunits. Similar procedures are used frequently for<br>T>1 icosahedrl viruses. One example that jumps to my [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-08T09:15:37-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;c387ab3e.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f3cc8d51.1503">   <title>C3 tetrameric symmetry </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f3cc8d51.1503</link>   <description> Hi<br><br>I'm working on a protein that has a tetrameric symmetry (symmetry: T).<br>Each face of the tetramer features an additional C3 symmetry.<br>Thus each particle has 12 asymmetric units.<br>My initial runs with symmetry=T (4 asymmetric units per boxed particle) where very successful, but now I'm interested in applying the whole/right symmetry during the refinement. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T10:06:05+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sebastian Scherer</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f3cc8d51.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb55ea55.1503">   <title>4TB dataset in EMPIAR </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb55ea55.1503</link>   <description> Dear all<br><br>Just to let you know - we now have a 4TB data set in EMPIAR (EMPIAR-10023; http://pdbe.org/empiar-10023). This is data for EMD-2852 (http://pdbe.org/emd-2852) - an ATP synthase dimer structure determined to 7A from the Kuehlbrandt and Davies groups.<br>As this is our first released TB+ dataset it would be very useful to have stats on how long it takes to download the data and `I am thankful to anyone who can email us the details! [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-05T09:07:18+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Ardan Patwardhan</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;fb55ea55.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6a5226ef.1503">   <title>Re: CTF star file </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6a5226ef.1503</link>   <description> If you cannot get this running, I would suggest just re-running the ctf<br>estimation.<br>HTH, S<br>On 03/02/2015 02:10 PM, Guan, Jian wrote:<br>&gt; Hi Sjors,<br>&gt; Thank you so much for your reply.<br>&gt; I tried it in command line. However it returned with error:<br>&gt; Error in textToFloat<br>&gt; File: src/strings.cpp line:176<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Could you please help me with that?<br>&gt; B.W. Are there any special requirements for the mrc files? Like, 16bit, 32bit or 64bit?<br>&gt; Thanks,<br>&gt; Have a good week.<br>&gt; Jian<br>&gt;<br>&gt; -----Original Message-----<br>> From: Collaborative Computational Project in Electron cryo-Microscopy [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-04T08:40:53+00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;6a5226ef.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f42f42e5.1503">   <title>Re: Flexibility </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f42f42e5.1503</link>   <description> Hi again,<br>The optimiser.star file has a _rlnSolventMaskName entry. Change that.<br>HTH, S<br>&gt; Dear Sjors,<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Thanks very much for your help.<br>&gt; I used chimera to remove one of the two \ufffd\ufffd domains \ufffd\ufffd and created a new<br>&gt; MRC file. Then, I used relion_mask_create command to create a mask.<br>&gt;<br>&gt; It is unclear to me what to modify in the model star file. I can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt see<br>&gt; any mention of the solvent mask in this file.<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Thanks again<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Best regards<br>&gt;<br>&gt; R\ufffd\ufffdmi<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt;<br>&gt; R\ufffd\ufffdmi Fronzes<br>> G5 [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-02T07:11:27-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;f42f42e5.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e9d5bc22.1503">   <title>Re: Flexibility </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e9d5bc22.1503</link>   <description> Dear Sjors,<br><br>Thanks very much for your help.<br>I used chimera to remove one of the two \ufffd\ufffd domains \ufffd\ufffd and created a new MRC file. Then, I used relion_mask_create command to create a mask.<br><br>It is unclear to me what to modify in the model star file. I can\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdt see any mention of the solvent mask in this file. [...]   </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T18:47:05+01:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>R\ufffd\ufffdmi Fronzes</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;e9d5bc22.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1453ffb4.1503">   <title>Re: CTF star file </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1453ffb4.1503</link>   <description> Hi Jian,<br>Sometimes jobs die due to glitches in the system. You may then miss your<br>star file. The program has an option --only_make_star that you can use in<br>this cases: it will only generate the star file, without having to re-run<br>the whole job.<br>HTH,<br>S<br><br>&gt; Hi Sjors,<br>&gt; I met a problem recently when I deal with movie data. I followed manual.<br>&gt; After ran the CTF estimation, it didn't generate the xxxx_ctf.star file.<br>&gt; However, I can find all ctf files in the Micrographs folder with for each<br>> mrc files, for example, ctffind3.com, and ctffind3.log. [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T10:10:50-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1453ffb4.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1debc541.1503">   <title>Re: masks and CTF </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1debc541.1503</link>   <description> Dear Linda,<br>Only the alignments (i.e. the posterior probability calculations in the<br>E-step) are performed using a 2D mask. The actual 3D reconstructions (or<br>2D class averages) are calculated from unmasked particles. This is where<br>the CTF correction takes place. Therefore, tight masking does not affect<br>the CTF correction.<br>HTH,<br>S<br><br>&gt; Dear All,<br>&gt; Does anyone know if the particle mask you specify influences the CTF<br>&gt; correction? My alignments benefit from a tight mask, but I was wondering<br>&gt; if<br>&gt; the CTF correction ignores this mask. Thank you.<br>&gt;<br>&gt; Best Wishes,<br>&gt; Linda Franken<br>&gt;    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T09:58:29-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1debc541.1503</dc:identifier> </item>  <item rdf:about="https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1a2fbf19.1503">   <title>Re: Flexibility </title>   <link>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1a2fbf19.1503</link>   <description> Hi Remi,<br>In relion-1.4 this will be easier: you can just start an autorefine from<br>local searches. In relion-1.3, you need to restart an old run from some<br>intermediate iteration and modify the model and optimiser.star files of<br>that iteration to provide the other mask. Just change the value for the<br>lab with the solvent mask.<br>HTH,<br>S [...]    </description>   <dc:date>2015-03-01T09:56:47-00:00</dc:date>   <dc:creator>Sjors Scheres</dc:creator>   <dc:identifier>https://www.jiscmail.ac.uk:443/cgi-bin/webadmin?A2=CCPEM;1a2fbf19.1503</dc:identifier> </item>   </rdf:RDF>
